articles.headline: Axios Wants Us to Read Everything in Bullet Points
articles.snippet: The news organization that prides itself on short-format writing has big plans to expand in local news, paid newsletters and even the emails sent by your bosses.
articles.abstract: The news organization that prides itself on short-format writing has big plans to expand in local news, paid newsletters and even the emails sent by your bosses.
articles.lead_paragraph: With much of the digital media world combining forces to survive, the founders of five-year-old Axios think they have the right recipe for success on their own.

articles.headline: Russia, Blocked From the Global Internet, Plunges Into Digital Isolation
articles.snippet: Russian authorities and multinational companies have erected a digital barricade between the country and the West, erasing the last remnants of independent information online.
articles.abstract: Russian authorities and multinational companies have erected a digital barricade between the country and the West, erasing the last remnants of independent information online.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even as President Vladimir V. Putin tightened his grip on Russian society over the past 22 years, small pockets of independent information and political expression remained online.
articles.byline: By Adam Satariano and Valerie Hopkins

articles.headline: With New Limits on Media, Putin Closes a Door on Russia’s ‘Openness’
articles.snippet: The Russian leader is undoing the social freedoms introduced at the end of the Soviet Union, risking a return to total control and ideological isolation.
articles.abstract: The Russian leader is undoing the social freedoms introduced at the end of the Soviet Union, risking a return to total control and ideological isolation.
articles.lead_paragraph: One of the paradoxical things about Vladimir V. Putin’s increasingly authoritarian rule of Russia was how relatively open society always remained.

articles.headline: U.S. Weighs Russian Oil Ban as Gas Prices Surge and Ukraine War Grows
articles.snippet: Global stocks dipped on Monday as U.S. officials discussed an oil cutoff, and gas prices hit a national average above $4, up more than 10 percent in a week.
articles.abstract: Global stocks dipped on Monday as U.S. officials discussed an oil cutoff, and gas prices hit a national average above $4, up more than 10 percent in a week.
articles.lead_paragraph: Biden is expected to ban Russian oil imports into the United States. Follow live updates.
articles.byline: By Alan Rappeport, Edward Wong and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: Supreme Court Allows Court-Imposed Voting Maps in North Carolina and Pennsylvania
articles.snippet: State courts had ruled that earlier maps for congressional elections had been warped by partisan gerrymandering. Democrats stand to benefit from the justices’ decision.
articles.abstract: State courts had ruled that earlier maps for congressional elections had been warped by partisan gerrymandering. Democrats stand to benefit from the justices’ decision.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court on Monday allowed congressional maps that had been approved by state courts in North Carolina and Pennsylvania to stand, giving Democrats an advantage in this year’s election in two key states.

articles.headline: Humanitarian Crisis Worsens for Ukrainians Trapped in Russia’s Onslaught
articles.snippet: Two weeks after the invasion began, tens of thousands of Ukrainians are without food, water or power. The Russians are increasingly resorting to indiscriminate shelling to help their forces advance.
articles.abstract: Two weeks after the invasion began, tens of thousands of Ukrainians are without food, water or power. The Russians are increasingly resorting to indiscriminate shelling to help their forces advance.
articles.lead_paragraph: MYKOLAIV, Ukraine — Increasingly indiscriminate Russian shelling that has trapped and traumatized Ukrainian civilians magnified fears on Monday of an intensifying humanitarian crisis that has already left tens of thousands without food, water, power or heat in besieged cities of southern Ukraine and elsewhere.
articles.byline: By Michael Schwirtz, Andrew E. Kramer and Rick Gladstone

articles.headline: As Russia’s Military Stumbles, Its Adversaries Take Note
articles.snippet: President Vladimir Putin could still reduce cities in Ukraine to rubble, officials say. But European countries say they are not as intimidated by Russian ground forces as they were in the past.
articles.abstract: President Vladimir Putin could still reduce cities in Ukraine to rubble, officials say. But European countries say they are not as intimidated by Russian ground forces as they were in the past.
articles.lead_paragraph: CONSTANTA, Romania — When it comes to war, generals say that “mass matters.”
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper, Eric Schmitt and Julian E. Barnes

articles.headline: Rising Gas Prices Have Drivers Asking, ‘Is This for Real?’
articles.snippet: The average price of a gallon of gasoline is up more than 10 percent in the last week, leading some consumers to rethink their routines and spending.
articles.abstract: The average price of a gallon of gasoline is up more than 10 percent in the last week, leading some consumers to rethink their routines and spending.
articles.lead_paragraph: After months of working from home, Caroline McNaney, 29, was excited about going back to work in an office, even if her new job in Trenton, N.J., meant commuting an hour each way.
articles.byline: By Michael Corkery, Emma Goldberg and Erin Woo

articles.headline: The Future Turns Dark for Russia’s Oil Industry
articles.snippet: An exodus by Western companies and disdain for Russian oil signal the start of a reckoning.
articles.abstract: An exodus by Western companies and disdain for Russian oil signal the start of a reckoning.
articles.lead_paragraph: A week after a chorus of Western executives from Exxon Mobil, BP, Shell and other companies denounced Moscow’s violent onslaught in Ukraine and pledged to pull their companies out of Russian ventures, it appears the turbulence for Russia’s energy industry has only begun.

articles.headline: Reality Intrudes on a Utopian Crypto Vision
articles.snippet: The cryptocurrency boom has spawned enterprises democratically governed by a community of users. Or that’s the theory. Making it work has been much messier.
articles.abstract: The cryptocurrency boom has spawned enterprises democratically governed by a community of users. Or that’s the theory. Making it work has been much messier.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American CryptoFed is a new kind of company spawned by the advent of cryptocurrency — one that claims, in a way, not to be a company at all.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Ephrat Livni

articles.headline: Ban on Russian Oil Could Hit the U.S. Economy as Gas Prices Rise
articles.snippet: The White House is stopping Russian energy imports as the country wages war on Ukraine, which could push American gas prices even higher.
articles.abstract: The White House is stopping Russian energy imports as the country wages war on Ukraine, which could push American gas prices even higher.
articles.lead_paragraph: The ban on Russian oil imports announced by President Biden on Tuesday could have meaningful consequences for the U.S. economy, pushing prices at the gas pump higher when inflation is already rapid, although how long-lasting that impact might be remains uncertain.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek and Alan Rappeport
